Mrs Phillips - Ramos - Rojas II
August 16, 1940
Mr. John J. Moran
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
Herewith I send you a rather extensive memorandum made from notes
and memory. It may be wrong in spots and I am most anxious to have you check
every detail as carefully as you can. I have only had four or five copies made.
One I am sending to Dr. Hutchison, president of Washington and Jefferson College,
one to General Kean, one to General Truby, whom I have contacted, one to Mr.
Pogolotti and one to Senora Rojas. As you will see, it is confidential. Some of
it will never be used for publication but merely as background information. From
this data, with additions from elsewhere, I will make my report to Dr. Ramos and
the Cuban government, and my paper for the Lazear Memorial dedication. If, in any
place, you see errors or misrepresentations of any sort, I will be only too grateful
for your full and thorough criticism, and since you cannot possibly take the trouble
to type your own answers, I will appreciate it greatly if you would get in touch
with Mrs. Phillips and at your mutual convenience, dictate to her as fulsomely
as you desire, whatever comes to your mind. I am writing her, asking her to act
as my agent in this matter, not only regarding your reply, but the replies of Mr.
Pogolotti and Senor Rojas. As my copies are limited, and I don't want them to get
out, would you please lend yours to Mrs. Phillips that she may read it over and
understand our problem before she gets in touch with Mr. Pogolotti and Senora
Rojas? This arrangement is not just to spare you, but I can assure you it is partly
selfish, as I want as detailed information as possible and think this is the best
way to get it. I hope you do not feel that it was indiscreet for me to let Mr.
Pogolotti and Senora Rojas, two Cubans, see these remarks. I am, of course, writing
them that my notes are confidential and asking for whatever corrections they see fit
to make.
Now as to some specific questions.

Paragraph 6: I still haven't found out what year the tent camp, that
is, Camp Columbia, was erected, what year it was replaced by the wooden buildings
of Columbia Barracks and when in turn they were torn down in favor of the present
Military City. I am also anxious to know what the site of Camp Columbia was used for
before it was used for that purpose. Do you have any idea where I can find these
things out? Perhaps Dr. Beato whom we met would be willing to help us on this.

Paragraph 7: What is the relationship between Quemados and Marianao?
Is the one merely a section of the latter? Is there one mayor or two? Perhaps the
mayor would know of some local historian who could find me some 1900 maps of Quemados.
They certainly must be in existence, in a library or some place. Please give me in
writing information as to just where Military Hospital No. 1 was on Principe Hill.
My recollection is that you told me it was where the General Garcia Hospital now is.
Is this the same as the University Hospital? Was the former name of Military Hospital
the Hospital Alfonso XIII, as indicated in my paragraph 107?

I wonder whether the Superintendent of this hospital could give
me reference to some historical paper or booklet concerning the hospital, and whether
he could tell me where I could find some old photograph of Military Hospital #1.

Paragraph 8: I have been unable to find any photographs of the post
hospital at Columbia Barracks, particularly of the officers' quarters there. Will
you in your own handwriting identify the buildings in the photograph which Kissinger
gave me? This photograph presumably was of Columbia Barracks. Photo. # 9 & 10

Paragraph 9: Do you know any details about the epidemic at Pinar
Del Rio? What were the relationships, rank and position of Dr. Cooke, Captain
Godfrey and Major Michie at Pinar?

Paragraph 14: Do you have any dope on this? Do you know where
Carroll was treated and where he convalesced? Was this at the post hospital at
Columbia Barracks?

Paragraphs 15 and 16: I wish you would dictate more specifically
your understanding regarding the inaccuracy of the official version of Lazear's
illness and the possibly true version which you mentioned to me and which has
since been amplified by Miss Agramonte and Generals Kean and Truby. Did Dr. Lazear
die in the post hospital at Columbia Barracks? Where was he buried? I understand
he was buried right near Camp Columbia. When and where the the body re-interred and
do you know where he is now buried.

Paragraph 22: Please give me your recollection as to the 11 soldiers
who went into residence at Camp Lazear on Nov. 20? Who was the exact personnel of
the camp?

Paragraph 23: The Infected Clothing Bldg. was ready for occupancy
Nov. 30. Do you know when this building was begun? Do you know whether any of
the nurses who took care of you and other experimental cases are still living?

Paragraph 27: The Infected Mosquito Bldg. No. 2 was ready for
occupancy Dec. 21. Do you know when its building was begun? I think it was Dec. 1.
Who were the two volunteers who slept for 18 nights in the mosquito-free side of
the Infected Mosquito Bldg.

Paragraph 28: What was the arrangement whereby you were inoculated
with infected blood after your experimental illness? Who did this and where was
it done? And did they bring the blood from Las Animas Hospital?

Paragraph 29: Did you hear anything about the disbanding of the camp
and whether the wooden buildings were torn down? You recall Senora Rojas told us
they were. Had you heard this at the time? Do you recall that you could see any
hilly country from Camp Lazear? You remember as we walked further away from Real
Street beyond the quarry, the country or rather the view of the country was quite
hilly. As no hills appear in any photographs of Camp Lazear, I think the camp
must have been much nearer Real Street than the end of the old quarry. Do you
remember from your own personal knowledge, the relationship of the camp to the Rojas
farm house, its distance or direction, and do you think that the buildings in the background. on the right
side of Photo. No. 16 might have been connected with the Rojas farm buildings?

Paragraph 32: Are my directions as to how to get to the false Camp
Lazear correct? Approximately how large is the territory covered by the Military
City? I am hoping Dr. Ramos can get me an old map of Camp Columbia and Columbia
Barracks, to compare its position and size with the present Military City. Am I
right about Calzada a los Quemados? How many units are there to the present hospital
Militar de Columbia? When was the Fourth of September Clinic erected? On one of
my pencil sketches made on our way from the false camp site, I infer that we went
down a “Boquetta Road” but this is unmarked on the maps. My recollection is that we
asked the name of the road we were traversing and you were told this name from one of
the local residents. But the maps indicate that one should go directly down Santa
Rosa Street to meet the railroad track. What is the relationship between Boquetta
Road and Santa Rosa Street and where should Boquetta Road be on the map? What does
“Linea Para Rero” mean? I have also asked Senora Rojas if they knew of some governmenta
tree expert who could visit the tree at the false site or look at our photographs of
this tree and tell us whether it is forty years old or not, and also possibly the age
of rhe framboyant and other trees hear the shacks beside the quarry near the true
site of Camp Lazear. I don't want you all to be hunting for an expert, but you might
collaborate on this point.

Photo 6
Reports
Pogolotti
Paragraphs 41 and 42: I am anxious to have your reaction to these.

Paragraph 53: I am asking Mr. Pogolotti and Senora Rojas to help on
this. What is the exact meaning of the words Tejar, finca etand Quinta? Are my directions
to reach the finca San Jose correct?

Paragraphs 59 to 67: I am asking Senora Rojas to check and amplify
these paragraphs as much as possible, but would appreciate your help too. Of
crucial importance is to have Senora Rojas mark in ink or pencil on (Map) No. Photos 1 & 2
her exact recollection of where Camp Lazear was in relation to the present quarry,
land and buildings. If you could see fit to accompany Mrs. Phillips when she
visits Senora Rojas, this might help tremendously, particularly in this point, and
I hope you will check her answer with my statements in Paras. 65 and 67. I am also
asking them who owns the quarry now, in the hope that the owner may have some old
photographs of the land before the quarries were begun.
Paragraph 86: Will you identify our meeting place?
Paragraphs 101 to 104: I want your reaction.
Paragraphs 115 to 116: I am anxious to have you check these.
Paragraphs 118: I want your opinion on this especially.

I assume you still have the wood. At least, I hope so. I have written
the Dept. of Agriculture here, asking if they will admit this wood, as it now is,
or whether I will have to have it already made into gavels, pen holders, etc.
I have never heard from the wood carver that we visited next to the (was it the
Paris) Restaurant. He was going to let us know whether he could have the wood dried
and was going to give me an idea what objects he could made and at what cost. I
do not believe I have his address, and I am somewhat concerned as the time is getting
short if we are going to have something made before October. I have asked Madam
Rojas' permission to obtain a limb from a tree nearest the true site of Camp Lazear.

Can you identify the building in Photo. No. 48 as the Fourth of Sept.
Clinic? I cannot tell you how much I appreciate your wonderful helpin all this.
But after all, you are partly to blame as you got me so much further involved in this
interesting story than I had ever intended. Let me thank you a thousand times for this
help.
